title: Allocation of slots at European Union airports: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on common rules for the allocation of slots at EU airports (recast)
background: The European Commission proposed recasting EU airport slot allocation rules in 2011 amid rising air traffic demand and constrained airport capacity, aiming to optimize infrastructure use. The Parliament will discuss regulatory reforms to establish common slot allocation rules, balancing operational efficiency, competition, and connectivity across EU airports.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly endorses maintaining the 80/20 historical slot allocation rule to preserve market stability and avoid disproportionate burdens on airlines, aligning with their commitment to predictable regulatory frameworks.  
EPP approves the elimination of the slot reservation fee as a necessary step to reduce operational costs for carriers while enhancing secondary market transparency to prevent speculative abuses.  
EPP emphasizes the need for stricter sanctions against slot misuse by airlines, proposing enhanced monitoring mechanisms in Annex II to ensure compliance without opposing the issue’s core structure.  
EPP advocates reinforcing social clauses in ground handling services, suggesting a minor amendment to Article 7 to mandate minimum training hours for workers while maintaining support for limited provider expansion.  
EPP endorses infrastructure capacity expansion measures but recommends adding explicit stakeholder consultation requirements in Article 12(b) to align technical upgrades with regional needs.

EFD opposes fundamentally the issue's consolidation of slot allocation rules which fail to dismantle entrenched privileges for incumbent airlines, directly conflicting with EFD's principle of open market competition.  
EFD rejects the proposal's silence on temporal priority considerations for noise regulation, inconsistent with their stance that individuals knowingly assuming proximity to airports bear responsibility for associated inconveniences.  
EFD highlights the issue's omission of mechanisms to empower new market entrants through dynamic slot redistribution, contradicting EFD's 2023 agenda for aviation sector liberalization.  
EFD criticizes the lack of binding criteria to differentiate between pre-existing residents and post-airport settlers in noise mitigation, a flaw EFD's transport policy explicitly prohibits.

GREEN_EFA firmly supports the issue's procedural integrity in codifying existing legislation without dilution of environmental safeguards, perfectly aligning with their constitutional commitment to legislative transparency.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's implicit rejection of ground handling liberalization that risks social dumping, upholding their manifesto pledge to protect airport workers' rights.  
The issue effectively advances GREEN_EFA's priority of local autonomy in noise management by maintaining current restrictions against economic interference, safeguarding communities from harmful nighttime operations.  
GREEN_EFA firmly supports the rejection of Commission overreach in regional flight curfews, reinforcing their decades-long advocacy for binding WHO noise standards over corporate interests.  
This legislative consolidation perfectly aligns with GREEN_EFA's systemic critique of aviation subsidies by preserving existing frameworks until full sectoral taxation parity is achieved.

ALDE strongly agrees maintaining member state autonomy in ground service liberalization to respect local airport conditions, aligning with their principle of subsidiarity.  
ALDE emphasizes that worker qualifications and fair labor conditions are critical for service quality enhancement, proposing amendments to include EU-wide training standards.  
ALDE approves the issue’s balanced approach to slot allocation efficiency while safeguarding smaller airlines’ operational needs through regular usage assessments.  
ALDE endorses procedural transparency measures ensuring national parliaments’ consultation, consistent with their advocacy for multilevel governance.  
ALDE highlights the necessity of infrastructure capacity evaluations before expanding service providers, framing this as operational realism rather than opposition to liberalization.

SD totally approves the codification of slot allocation mechanisms to optimize airport capacity utilization, particularly praising the strengthened coordinator role and infrastructure reinvestment provisions as perfect realizations of transport efficiency goals.  
SD perfectly aligns with the harmonized noise regulation framework’s balance between EU-wide standards and local subsidiarity, recognizing it as a model for reconciling environmental and operational priorities.  
SD highlights enhancement opportunities to extend the 80-20 rule’s flexibility for multi-season scheduling while maintaining full procedural adherence to Treaty obligations under Articles 294(2) and 100(2).  
SD unequivocally supports transparency in slot trading markets as critical to preventing monopolistic practices, mirroring their manifesto commitment to fair competition in transport infrastructure.  
 Opposition to groundhandling liberalization concerns separate legislative acts; on the recast slot rules specifically, SD maintains unqualified endorsement.

ECR rejects the slot allocation proposal's failure to substantively advance market liberalization, absolutely againsting with their core principle of open competition.  
ECR opposes the issue's preservation of existing slot rules as inconsistent with their demand for evidence-based reforms to airport capacity constraints.  
ECR absolutely againsts with the noise regulation's shift to EU-level prescriptiveness, directly contradicting their subsidiarity stance on local governance of airport impacts.  
ECR opposes the mandatory rehiring clauses in groundhandling provisions, viewing them as anti-competitive market distortions incompatible with free enterprise principles.  
ECR rejects the proposal's static approach to slot trading proceeds distribution, which disregards their position on market-driven allocation of aviation assets.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the adoption of its position at first reading on the Commission’s proposal to codify existing legislation without introducing substantive changes, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services, which concluded the proposal merely consolidated prior acts and amendments without altering their substance. The resolution emphasized adherence to the Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union (Articles 294(2) and 100(2)) and called on the Commission to resubmit the proposal to Parliament if substantial revisions or replacements were planned. It instructed the President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring transparency and procedural continuity in the legislative process.

title: European Maritime Safety Agency: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 1406/2002 establishing a European Maritime Safety Agency
background: Major offshore oil spills, including the 2010 Deepwater Horizon disaster and 2011 Gannet Alpha leak, highlighted risks to marine environments from oil and gas operations. Existing EU maritime safety frameworks focused on vessel-related pollution, while EMSA's mandate centered on ship safety and pollution response. The Parliament will discuss expanding EMSA's regulatory scope to address offshore installation safety and cross-border maritime challenges.

stances.stance:
EFD rejects the issue's budgetary constraints as undermining EMSA's capacity to operate beyond EU borders, contradicting their demand for expanded technical cooperation with third countries.  
EFD opposes the procedural requirement for Commission re-engagement with Parliament, deeming it a bureaucratic barrier to swift pollution response efforts prioritized by their platform.  
The proposal completely doubts with EFD's insistence on unambiguous task delineation, risking under-resourced mandates that could perpetuate operational duplication.  
EFD condemns the issue's budgetary neutrality principle as incompatible with their vision of a fully integrated European maritime space without barriers.  
 While advocating for EMSA's expanded role, the EFD argument does not explicitly address Treaty adherence clauses central to the issue's framework.

GREEN_EFA strongly approves the expanded monitoring of offshore oil and gas installations, aligning perfectly with their commitment to preventing environmental disasters and ensuring marine ecosystem protection.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s emphasis on maritime accident preparedness, which effectively advances their priority of climate resilience and proactive crisis management in EU waters.  
GREEN_EFA commends the integration of SafeSeaNet and maritime surveillance partnerships, proposing enhanced linkage with biodiversity protection frameworks under the EU’s integrated maritime policy as a strategic enhancement.  
GREEN_EFA endorses the issue’s adherence to budgetary neutrality, recognizing this as critical to maintaining institutional accountability while scaling EMSA’s operational capacity.  
GREEN_EFA highlights EMSA’s Lisbon operations as exemplary implementation of maritime safety goals, urging replication of its collaborative model in other EU agencies.

ALDE strongly promotes the enhanced coordination of maritime safety resources through EMSA’s expanded mandate, aligning perfectly with ALDE’s longstanding commitment to efficient, supranational solutions for transboundary environmental and security challenges.  
ALDE applauds the integration of satellite monitoring for anti-piracy operations, which effectively advances ALDE’s priority of leveraging innovation to strengthen maritime security and crisis response capabilities.  
ALDE proposes reinforcing regional actors’ inclusion in future disaster response frameworks, noting their proven effectiveness during incidents like the Prestige spill, to ensure localized expertise complements EU-level coordination.  
ALDE urges amendments to incorporate gender balance in EMSA’s governance structures, aligning with broader EU equality goals while maintaining strong backing for the agency’s operational modernization.  
ALDE endorses cross-border cooperation with Norway and Iceland, emphasizing that EMSA’s expanded assistance to neighboring states reflects shared maritime safety imperatives beyond EU borders.

SD strongly upholds expanding EMSA’s mandate to include pollution prevention and piracy deterrence, aligning with their longstanding commitment to maritime safety and environmental protection.  
SD approves the addition of 14 new operational tasks but proposes a financial review mechanism to ensure adequate resources without compromising existing priorities.  
SD endorses EMSA’s enhanced coordination role in transnational zones like the English Channel, emphasizing unified safety standards to address privatized service gaps.  
SD advocates integrating EU space programs (EGNOS, GALILEO) into EMSA’s monitoring systems to advance technological innovation for maritime efficiency.  
SD strongly upholds extending EMSA’s safety inspections to offshore oil installations, citing Deepwater Horizon as critical justification for centralized European oversight.

ECR fundamentally disputes the expansion of EMSA's mandate into inland waterways and offshore installations, viewing it as unnecessary duplication of existing national and international efforts.  
ECR rejects the creation of a European coastguard service, asserting that national coastguards already cooperate effectively and additional EU structures are redundant.  
ECR highlights that extending EMSA's competencies to oil/gas platform inspections contradicts the principle of subsidiarity, as member states already maintain rigorous monitoring systems.  
ECR criticizes the proposal's failure to address budgetary impacts, particularly during economic challenges, deeming expanded mandates unjustified without clear cost-benefit analysis.

GUE_NGL rejects the expansion of EMSA’s mandate into piracy and coastguard operations, which totally doubts with their focus on maritime safety and environmental protection as core priorities.  
GUE_NGL opposes the proposal’s diversion of EMSA’s resources toward security-related tasks, overlooking critical aspects like pollution from shore industries and fish farms that require urgent scientific intervention.  
GUE_NGL condemns the issue’s failure to explicitly restrict EMSA’s role to its original mission, risking institutional overreach inconsistent with their principles of targeted environmental governance.  
GUE_NGL highlights the proposal’s neglect of budgetary neutrality in expanding EMSA’s scope, which undermines accountability and could divert funds from pollution prevention programs.  
GUE_NGL demands strict adherence to Treaty obligations under Article 100(2) TFEU, rejecting any amendments that dilute EMSA’s focus on accident prevention and maritime worker safety.

resolution: The European Parliament raised the application of point 47 of the Interinstitutional Agreement of 17 May 2006 on budgetary discipline and sound financial management to the extension of tasks of the European Maritime Safety Agency (EMSA), emphasizing that such extensions must not preempt decisions by the budgetary authority during annual budget procedures. It adopted its first-reading position on the Commission’s 2010 proposal (COM(2010)0611) and stressed the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if intending to substantially amend or replace the proposal, ensuring continued legislative oversight. The resolution underscored adherence to Treaty provisions (Article 100(2) TFEU) and procedural frameworks while prioritizing budgetary neutrality and institutional accountability in expanding EMSA’s mandate.

title: Aerodromes, air traffic management and air navigation services: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 216/2008 in the field of aerodromes, air traffic management and air navigation services
background: Fragmented European airspace management caused inefficiencies, delays, higher operational costs compared to global counterparts, and environmental concerns due to suboptimal flight routes. Existing Single European Sky regulations (SES I/II) faced implementation challenges in harmonising national systems. The Parliament will discuss regulatory amendments to enhance air traffic efficiency, safety standards, and operational integration across member states.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly sanctions the integration of the Single European Sky to enhance economic competitiveness, job creation, and aviation safety, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to a unified European transport policy.  
EPP applauds the issue's environmental efficiency measures and urges accelerated implementation to optimize flight routes, reduce CO2 emissions, and lower fuel consumption.  
EPP endorses the advancement of SESAR deployment through regulatory measures, ensuring Europe's global leadership in aeronautical innovation and interoperability.  
EPP proposes strengthening provisions to ensure fair market conditions for smaller air navigation providers and newer member states, while maintaining balanced regulatory oversight to prevent excessive centralization.  
EPP recommends clarifying performance plan consultation requirements to address concerns about disproportionate impacts on regional operational flexibility.

GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue’s emphasis on cross-border airspace cooperation, recognizing its critical role in reducing emissions through optimized flight routes.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally sanctions the rejection of rigid service separation mandates, affirming that context-specific governance models better serve both efficiency and sovereignty concerns.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the need to enhance democratic scrutiny of delegated acts, proposing strengthened parliamentary oversight mechanisms to prevent regulatory overreach.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the issue’s alignment with functional airspace block progress, particularly its indirect support for reducing military airspace restrictions as a climate mitigation measure.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes that the issue’s procedural rigor under Article 100(2) TFEU advances their vision of EU-wide ecological standardization in aviation governance.

ALDE entirely supports the Commission’s proposal to integrate Gibraltar Airport into EU aviation legislation, perfectly aligning with their commitment to seamless cross-border air traffic cooperation under the Single European Sky framework.  
ALDE perfectly aligns with the issue’s focus on eliminating airspace fragmentation, emphasizing its critical role in reducing €3 billion annual inefficiencies and advancing Europe’s environmental sustainability goals.  
ALDE strongly upholds the rejection of national territorial disputes in aviation policy, asserting that Gibraltar’s inclusion is essential for operational coherence and EU legal consistency.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s adherence to Treaty obligations under Article 100(2) TFEU, which effectively advances their priority of supranational governance in transport infrastructure.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgency of implementing the Single European Sky to alleviate airport congestion and strengthen Europe’s global aviation competitiveness, as outlined in their 2013 policy priorities.

SD strongly endorses the implementation of the Single European Sky framework, aligning perfectly with their commitment to environmental sustainability and reducing operational costs for airlines and passengers.  
SD approves the issue’s emphasis on centralized performance monitoring mechanisms, which directly advance their priority of transparent, interoperable air navigation services.  
SD proposes strengthening social impact assessments during national implementation to address workforce concerns while maintaining reform momentum.  
SD highlights the critical need to retain "safety" in the European Aviation Safety Agency’s name and mandate, ensuring clarity in its core mission.  
SD urges structured collaboration between member states to harmonize technical systems, addressing fragmentation without compromising national operational expertise.

ECR strongly promotes the Single European Sky initiative’s potential to boost air traffic efficiency and reduce CO2 emissions, aligning with ECR’s commitment to sustainable transport and economic growth.  
ECR urges full inclusion of Gibraltar in the Single Sky framework, upholding the 2006 Córdoba Agreement and rejecting discriminatory amendments that violate treaty obligations.  
ECR proposes maintaining national supervisory authorities to avoid legal complexities, advocating for decentralized oversight that respects member states’ sovereignty.  
ECR recommends a comprehensive impact assessment prior to restructuring the Performance Review Body, ensuring evidence-based enhancements to its independence.  
ECR emphasizes the need to evaluate existing SES frameworks before implementing new structural changes, balancing innovation with regulatory stability.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal as fully disputeing with their opposition to ultraliberal aviation policies that prioritize corporate interests over public safety and workers' rights.  
GUE/NGL opposes the dismantling of national air traffic control structures, which would privatize critical services and risk safety through underpaid, precarious labor conditions.  
GUE/NGL condemns the market-driven approach to airspace management as incompatible with their commitment to public ownership and sovereignty over strategic transport infrastructure.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal’s failure to address safety risks from fragmented navigation services, directly contradicting their demand for rigorous aviation safety standards.  
GUE/NGL rejects the issue’s alignment with airline industry deregulation, which threatens thousands of jobs in peripheral EU states and undermines environmental sustainability goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0409) concerning transport and tourism policy, while addressing a subsidiarity objection from the Maltese House of Representatives. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and mandated the transmission of its position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. It incorporated input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report and acknowledged the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion, emphasizing procedural adherence to Treaty obligations under Article 100(2) TFEU.

title: Compensation and assistance to passengers in the event of denied boarding and of cancellation or long delay of flights: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Regulation (EC) No 261/2004 establishing common rules on compensation and assistance to passengers in the event of denied boarding and of cancellation or long delay of flights and Regulation (EC) No 2027/97 on air carrier liability in respect of the carriage of passengers and their baggage by air
background: Persistent inconsistencies in applying EU air passenger rights regulations, including varied enforcement, ambiguous exemptions for extraordinary circumstances, and operational disruptions affecting compensation claims, prompted legal challenges and calls for clarity. The Parliament will discuss amending rules on compensation and assistance for denied boarding, cancellations, or delays to address enforcement gaps and passenger protection.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly advocates the balanced approach enhancing passenger rights while maintaining airline operational viability, aligning with EPP's commitment to consumer protection and market efficiency.  
EPP applauds the issue's transparency measures requiring clear pre-booking information and accessible complaint mechanisms at airports, advancing passenger empowerment.  
EPP endorses the standardized compensation bands as a fair solution to inconsistent national interpretations, though proposes reviewing the three-hour delay threshold to prevent unintended flight cancellations.  
EPP approves the prohibition of punitive no-show policies for multi-leg journeys, ensuring contractual fairness for travelers through coordinated EU rules.  
EPP emphasizes the issue's alignment with EPP priorities through its binding dispute issue systems and explicit definitions of "extraordinary circumstances" to reduce litigation risks.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the strengthened passenger compensation framework reducing eligibility thresholds to three hours, directly advancing consumer rights against airline monopolies.  
GREEN_EFA approves narrowing "extraordinary circumstances" exemptions to prevent abusive airline practices, aligning with European Court of Justice jurisprudence.  
GREEN_EFA applauds mandatory environmental impact disclosures on tickets as critical for empowering climate-conscious travel decisions.  
GREEN_EFA proposes amending Article 14 to require airlines to prominently display compensation claim procedures at check-in counters and via SMS alerts.  
GREEN_EFA highlights unresolved tax inequities favoring airlines as requiring separate legislative action to achieve parity with rail sustainability efforts.

ALDE strongly upholds the enhanced compensation framework for flight disruptions, aligning with their longstanding commitment to robust consumer protections in air travel.  
ALDE approves the 90-minute buffer period for regional carriers as a balanced approach to maintain connectivity while safeguarding passenger rights.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 3 to remove Gibraltar’s exclusion clause, ensuring equal application of passenger rights across all EU territories.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical importance of disability accommodations, particularly crew training and service animal provisions, as exemplary advancements in inclusive transport policy.  
ALDE highlights baggage rule clarifications and return-flight flexibility as key enhancements that align with their consumer empowerment priorities.

SD strongly upholds the strict limitation of "extraordinary circumstances" definitions to prevent airline abuse of technical issues, aligning perfectly with SD's consumer protection priorities.  
SD applauds the introduction of delay compensation rights as critical progress in passenger justice, effectively advancing SD's manifesto commitment to traveler dignity.  
SD endorses enhanced transparency through mandatory all-inclusive pricing displays and airport assistance points, matching SD's decade-long push against hidden fees.  
SD proposes strengthening accessibility provisions by requiring immediate wheelchair/special equipment return post-flight to fully uphold disabled passengers' rights.  
SD emphasizes the issue's alignment with SD's transport equity agenda through binding airline liability for cancellations and simplified claims procedures.

ECR entirely condemns the issue's exclusion of Gibraltar from passenger rights protections, conflicting with their principle of equal treatment for all EU citizens.  
ECR rejects the regulation’s failure to prohibit airlines from denying return flights due to unused outbound segments, contradicting fair contractual obligations.  
ECR opposes the ambiguous definition of "extraordinary circumstances," which inadequately excludes technical maintenance failures despite carriers’ operational responsibilities.  
ECR rejects the proposal’s potential to increase airfare costs through excessive consumer safeguards, inconsistent with market efficiency priorities.  
ECR entirely condemns the lack of explicit requirements for passenger disembarkation during prolonged tarmac delays, disregarding basic dignity protections.

GUE/NGL strongly sanctions the issue's balanced compromise enhancing passenger rights, particularly improved care for vulnerable groups and transparent claim procedures, aligning with their commitment to social justice and consumer protection.  
GUE/NGL approves the extended deadlines for compensation claims and airlines' response obligations, which ensure timely issue and uphold passenger rights as advocated in their policies.  
GUE/NGL highlights the inclusion of provisions for musical instruments and protection against denied boarding on connecting flights as critical advancements in passenger entitlements.  
GUE/NGL proposes amending the classification of flights to ultra-peripheral regions under Article 2(16) to ensure equal compensation treatment, thereby strengthening territorial cohesion in line with EU principles.  
GUE/NGL commends the EC's passenger rights application and urges expanded accessibility features for non-digital users to ensure inclusivity across all demographics.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0130) concerning transport-related regulations under Treaty Articles 294(2) and 100(2), informed by the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s report (A7-0020/2014) and the Committee on the Internal Market and Consumer Protection’s opinion. It adopted its first-reading stance, emphasizing the need for alignment with internal market and consumer protection principles, and urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing substantial amendments to the original text. The resolution further instructed the President to communicate Parliament’s position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, ensuring procedural continuity while prioritizing substantive coherence with EU treaty frameworks and stakeholder consultations, including the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion.

title: Deployment of the interoperable EU-wide eCall: REPORT on the proposal for a decision of the European Parliament and of the Council on the deployment of the interoperable EU-wide eCall
background: Persistent road safety challenges and insufficient voluntary adoption of emergency call technology prompted the European Commission's 2013 proposal for mandatory vehicle-integrated eCall systems using the EU-wide 112 emergency number, requiring cross-border infrastructure coordination. The Parliament will discuss establishing interoperable eCall deployment standards to improve emergency response efficiency and reduce traffic accident fatalities.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly approves the mandatory implementation of eCall in all vehicles, aligning with their longstanding commitment to road safety innovation and saving thousands of lives annually through rapid emergency response.  
EPP firmly promotes the privacy safeguards ensuring eCall remains dormant until activated by severe collisions, perfectly reflecting their balanced approach to technological innovation and fundamental rights protection.  
EPP proposes enhancing public awareness campaigns to clarify eCall's non-tracking functionality and manual activation options, addressing potential citizen concerns while maintaining full support for the system's deployment timeline.  
EPP strongly approves the rejection of an on/off switch for eCall, prioritizing passenger safety over optional configurations as consistent with their family protection values and duty-of-care principles.  
EPP emphasizes the critical need for member states to upgrade emergency infrastructure and 112 services to fully realize eCall's life-saving potential across all EU regions, urging swift ratification of related funding mechanisms.

GREEN_EFA rejects the mandatory eCall system as totally condemning with their principles of proportionality and data protection, emphasizing unresolved tracking risks under Article 5.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the issue's industry-centric approach, highlighting its inconsistency with consumer protection priorities stated in the Internal Market Committee's mandate.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the proposal for diverting funds from proven safety measures like speed limit enforcement, which the Transport Committee failed to prioritize.  
GREEN_EFA challenges the legislative intent's coherence by demonstrating how automated eCall fails to address infrastructure gaps and ambulance response times cited in recital 12.  
GREEN_EFA fundamentally disputes the proportionality justification, noting the issue's omission of hacking vulnerabilities despite Parliament's 2013 cybersecurity directives.

ALDE strongly advocates the eCall system's potential to reduce emergency response times and save lives, aligning with ALDE's commitment to advancing EU-wide transport safety innovations.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 4 to mandate an on/off switch for the eCall device, ensuring citizens retain autonomy over data transmission while preserving the system's core functionality.  
ALDE emphasizes the critical need for strict data protection safeguards in Annex II to prevent misuse by insurers, law enforcement, or third parties, reflecting ALDE's prioritization of digital privacy rights.  
ALDE approves the issue's cross-sectoral coordination with industry and consumer committees but urges explicit guarantees in Recital 9 that emergency infrastructure upgrades will precede full deployment.  
ALDE highlights the necessity for periodic system reviews under Article 7 to assess GPS accuracy and mobile network coverage gaps, transforming implementation challenges into continuous improvement opportunities.

SD strongly agrees the mandatory 112-linked eCall system as a public safety imperative, aligning with their commitment to reduce road fatalities through rapid emergency response while maintaining strict data privacy safeguards.  
SD approves the 2015 deadline for PSAP infrastructure upgrades, urging member states to prioritize technical readiness to ensure seamless pan-EU interoperability as outlined in Articles 4-6.  
SD proposes supplementing the issue with binding awareness campaigns to educate citizens on eCall’s dormant functionality, addressing concerns about low public familiarity raised during committee deliberations.  
SD endorses the prohibition of non-essential data collection, emphasizing that the adopted privacy-by-design approach effectively prevents unauthorized tracking as demanded in their 2014 transport manifesto.  
SD applauds the issue’s cost-benefit alignment, noting projected annual savings of €26 billion through reduced medical and congestion costs directly advance social welfare priorities.

ECR partially approves the interoperability framework but requests revisions to Article 4 mandating eCall deployment, citing unresolved privacy risks in vehicle data transmission protocols.  
ECR fully conflicts with mandatory installation requirements, emphasizing the issue overlooks critical aspects of consumer autonomy demonstrated by UK cost-benefit analyses.  
ECR rejects centralized data handling provisions as inconsistent with subsidiarity principles, demanding amendments to limit third-party access in emergency response networks.  
ECR requests infrastructure harmonization timelines be extended by 18 months to address Member State implementation capacity disparities noted in transport committee opinions.  
ECR opposes cross-border data retention clauses, proposing deletion of Paragraph 12(a) to align with their 2014 position on telematics regulation.

GUE/NGL partially promotes the eCall proposal only if amended to mandate an on/off switch enabling driver control over data transmission, directly addressing privacy invasions criticized by Cornelis de Jong.  
GUE/NGL requests revising Article 4 to explicitly prohibit insurers and third parties from accessing eCall data, countering Thomas Händel's warnings about commercial exploitation of accident information.  
GUE/NGL entirely disapproves the issue's "one-size-fits-all" deployment timeline as incompatible with member states' unprepared 112 infrastructure, echoing concerns about unworkable implementation timelines.  
GUE/NGL demands deletion of Clause 7(b) permitting continuous vehicle tracking, which conflicts with their anti-surveillance principles and enables police "movement profiling" risks highlighted in debate.  
GUE/NGL requires amendments limiting data retention to emergency scenarios only, rejecting the proposal's failure to prevent permanent storage of location histories inconsistent with EU privacy standards.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 proposal (COM(2013)0315) concerning transport policy, adopting its first-reading stance to advance legislative procedures under Article 91 of the Treaty on the Functioning of the EU. It emphasized the need for the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments or alternative texts, ensuring alignment with legislative intent. The resolution reflected input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, alongside opinions from the Committees on Industry, Research and Energy and the Internal Market and Consumer Protection, underscoring cross-sectoral priorities. Parliament instructed its President to formally transmit its adopted position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, reinforcing procedural transparency and interinstitutional coordination. The resolution aimed to uphold parliamentary oversight while advancing policy coherence in EU transport initiatives.

title: Further development of an integrated maritime policy: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a Programme to support the further development of an Integrated Maritime Policy
background: The European Union’s maritime sectors, contributing significantly to GDP, required cross-sectoral coordination under the 2007 Integrated Maritime Policy. Existing pilot projects highlighted gaps in governance, environmental protection, and economic synergies. The Parliament will discuss establishing a funding programme to enhance integrated maritime policy development and address sectoral challenges.

stances.stance:
EFD supports the issue’s emphasis on integrating maritime economic development with ecosystem preservation, aligning with EFD’s focus on sustainable growth.  
EFD advises amending Article 8 to mandate dedicated funding for improving transport connectivity between islands and mainland regions to bolster economic cohesion.  
EFD recommends revising Section 4 to explicitly link coastal tourism strategies with biodiversity conservation targets, ensuring balanced policy implementation.  
EFD endorses provisions for outermost regions but urges stricter monitoring mechanisms in Annex II to assess equitable resource allocation.  
EFD highlights the need for cross-sectoral coordination in energy efficiency measures, proposing an interagency task force under Article 11 to prevent policy fragmentation.

GREEN_EFA strongly promotes the allocation of EUR 40 million for integrated maritime policy development, particularly its focus on marine environment protection and illegal fishing detection as critical to ecological stewardship.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the collaboration with the European Maritime Safety Agency and SafeSeaNet, recognizing this partnership as essential for advancing maritime safety and sustainable surveillance practices.  
GREEN_EFA welcomes the issue’s cross-sectoral coherence in linking transport, fisheries, and regional development, aligning with their principles of holistic sustainability and economic cohesion.  
GREEN_EFA proposes enhancing future funding mechanisms to prioritize climate-resilient maritime infrastructure while maintaining strong support for the current interim budget framework.  
GREEN_EFA affirms the urgency of adopting sea-basin strategies as a proactive measure to address regional marine challenges, consistent with their advocacy for ecosystem-based governance.

ALDE strongly upholds the issue's integrated governance framework, aligning perfectly with their commitment to cross-sectoral policy coherence and sustainable maritime development.  
ALDE applauds the Atlantic Arc strategy's inclusion as a transformative tool for regional economic growth, particularly in renewable energy and coastal community revitalization.  
ALDE endorses the EUR 40 million funding allocation for cross-border projects, emphasizing its critical role in advancing ocean energy research and maritime infrastructure modernization.  
ALDE highlights the issue's strengthened environmental safeguards as exemplary alignment with EU sustainability goals, particularly in deep-sea ecosystem protection.  
ALDE proposes amending Article 9 to prioritize Fisheries Fund flexibility for small-port marina development, mirroring successful rural development models under the Common Agricultural Policy.

SD strongly upholds the issue's cross-sectoral integration of maritime planning, particularly its alignment with sustainable coastal development and offshore renewable energy expansion as critical to SD's environmental priorities.  
SD proposes enhancing Article 4 to explicitly mandate EU-funded observatories for deep-sea research, leveraging regions like the Azores to advance blue biotechnology and mineral resource mapping.  
SD applauds the emphasis on Black Sea corridor funding parity with other sea basins, urging swift adoption of a dedicated TEN-T budget line to implement the rapporteur's geostrategic vision.  
SD endorses binding provisions for third-country sustainability partnerships in fisheries management, aligning with the issue's ecosystem balance objectives and SD's global environmental justice commitments.  
SD recommends amending Annex II to include workforce retraining programs for coastal communities transitioning to green shipping technologies, ensuring the €40 million allocation directly supports just ecological transitions.

ECR partly supports the maritime policy framework but requests revisions to Article 5 to include explicit safeguards against disproportionate regulatory burdens on national shipbuilding industries.  
ECR fully disputes the issue's failure to address infrastructure inequities, citing the Nord Stream pipeline's obstruction of Polish port development as inconsistent with EU cohesion principles under Article 174 TFEU.  
ECR demands amendment of funding allocation clauses to mandate 30% of the EUR 40 million stimulus fund be directed to vocational training programs for maritime careers, addressing workforce prestige concerns.  
ECR rejects any budgetary provisions allowing consultant expenditures, insisting on strict limitations to "prevent theoretical strategizing" and prioritize tangible green shipping technology investments.  
ECR highlights unresolved contradictions between the issue's environmental goals and existing energy infrastructure projects that disadvantage member states' maritime economies.

GUE_NGL supports the Integrated Maritime Policy's sustainability goals but advises restructuring its governance framework to prioritize voluntary member state collaboration over top-down federalism, as outlined in Articles 91(1) and 194(2).  
GUE_NGL proposes amending provisions linking the policy to EU foreign policy objectives, advocating instead for explicit safeguards guaranteeing member states’ sovereignty over territorial waters and resource management.  
GUE_NGL highlights concerns that the issue’s current legal bases risk conflating environmental cooperation with supranational jurisdictional overreach, contradicting principles of subsidiarity in maritime governance.  
GUE_NGL recommends reinforcing regional development clauses to ensure coastal communities’ equitable access to marine resources, aligning with Article 43(2) on sustainable agricultural and fisheries practices.  
GUE_NGL acknowledges the policy’s potential to resolve cross-border maritime conflicts but urges binding mechanisms to prevent corporate exploitation of shared waters under the guise of energy efficiency.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on a legislative proposal by adopting a resolution grounded in multiple Treaty provisions, including Articles 43(2) on agriculture, 91(1) on transport, 192(1) on environmental policy, and 194(2) on energy, while integrating input from committees on Transport and Tourism, Fisheries, Environment, and Regional Development. The resolution emphasized alignment with EU objectives in sustainability, economic cohesion, and cross-sectoral policy coherence, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial amendments arise. It underscored legal bases spanning transport safety, environmental protection, regional development, and energy efficiency, reflecting a holistic approach to legislative harmonization across member states.

title: Implementation of the Single European Sky: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the implementation of the Single European Sky (recast)
background: Persistent fragmentation of European air traffic management caused inefficiencies, high operational costs, delays, and environmental concerns despite prior SES initiatives. The European Commission proposed a recast regulation to address structural barriers and integrate airspace. The Parliament will discuss implementing the Single European Sky to enhance efficiency, safety, and sustainability in aviation.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds the integration of European airspace to overcome fragmentation, aligning perfectly with their commitment to economic growth and job creation in aviation sectors.  
EPP approves the issue's emphasis on SESAR deployment as critical for maintaining Europe's global aerospace leadership through technological innovation.  
EPP highlights the environmental urgency of streamlined flight routes to reduce CO₂ emissions, advancing their climate action priorities while cutting operational costs.  
EPP proposes enhancing Article 6's governance framework to ensure equitable market access for smaller member states, safeguarding against monopolistic consolidation of air navigation services.  
EPP emphasizes harmonized air traffic control as vital for passenger safety and shorter travel times, consistent with their cross-border infrastructure modernization goals.

GREEN_EFA completely approves the issue's rigorous adherence to subsidiarity principles, perfectly aligning with our foundational commitment to respecting national competencies in airspace sovereignty while advancing EU-wide coordination.  
GREEN_EFA applauds the codification of existing legal frameworks as a critical safeguard against regulatory fragmentation, effectively advancing our priority of harmonized environmental and operational standards in aviation.  
GREEN_EFA perfectly aligns with the issue's procedural rigor, particularly its compliance with Article 100(2) TFEU and the Interinstitutional Agreement, which fortify democratic accountability in delegated acts and prevent executive overreach.  
GREEN_EFA strongly accepts the acknowledgment of improved airspace cooperation and reduced military restrictions, mirroring our advocacy for incremental, sovereignty-sensitive progress in trans-European transport efficiency.  
GREEN_EFA commends the issue's rejection of ideologically driven service separation mandates, reinforcing our principle that member state-specific assessments must govern aviation service reforms.

ALDE strongly accepts the implementation of the Single European Sky, aligning perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to EU integration and cross-border infrastructure efficiency.  
ALDE emphasizes the urgent need to eliminate airspace fragmentation, which directly advances ALDE's priority of reducing CO2 emissions and unlocking €3 billion in annual economic savings.  
ALDE proposes strengthening the legislation by rejecting amendments excluding Gibraltar Airport, ensuring seamless coordination with Spanish air traffic control as a critical enhancement opportunity.  
ALDE applauds the issue’s adherence to EU law applicability, particularly noting Gibraltar’s status as part of the Union, which matches ALDE’s principle of non-discrimination in transnational systems.  
ALDE urges Member States to depoliticize technical airspace management, framing exclusionary amendments as counterproductive to the Single European Sky’s environmental and operational goals.

SD supports the issue's emphasis on performance-based mechanisms to align member states with SES objectives, while advising enhanced social partner consultations to address workforce impacts.  
SD endorses streamlining air traffic management structures but proposes amending provisions to require socioeconomic impact assessments before functional airspace block implementation.  
SD approves environmental efficiency goals through optimized flight paths but recommends specifying fuel consumption reduction targets in Annex II.  
SD advises maintaining "safety" in the aviation agency's title (Article 7) to reflect core priorities, while urging budget adjustments to match expanded responsibilities.  
SD highlights the need for concrete revenue distribution frameworks between air navigation providers to ensure equitable implementation.

ECR fully doubts the centralization of national aviation authorities as proposed, which violates subsidiarity principles and would require impractical legal overhauls in member states.  
ECR rejects the premature implementation timeline, arguing the proposal undermines national sovereignty by introducing structural changes before evaluating existing SES frameworks.  
ECR condemns the exclusion of Gibraltar from the Single Sky provisions as a politically motivated breach of the 2006 Córdoba Agreement and EU treaty obligations.  
ECR opposes weakening member states’ decision-making autonomy over airspace management, citing unresolved competence conflicts between EU bodies and national governments.  
ECR highlights the proposal’s failure to address border sovereignty concerns, particularly regarding Spanish attempts to politicize aviation infrastructure against British territories.

GUE_NGL rejects the SES 2+ proposal as completely rejecting with their commitment to public ownership of critical infrastructure and worker protections.  
GUE_NGL opposes the issue's market-driven approach, warning it prioritizes airline profits over passenger safety through privatization of air traffic control.  
This proposal dangerously undermines national sovereignty in airspace management, contradicting GUE_NGL's principle of subsidiarity in transport policy.  
The issue's failure to address job precarity for aviation workers directly conflicts with GUE_NGL's labor rights agenda.  
GUE_NGL condemns the lack of environmental safeguards in the proposal, highlighting its incompatibility with sustainable transport goals.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2013 legislative proposal (COM(2013)0410), affirming that the text constitutes a codification of existing legal provisions without substantive amendments, as confirmed by the Consultative Working Party of the legal services. It acknowledged Malta’s subsidiarity concerns, which argued the proposal overstepped national competencies, and noted the European Economic and Social Committee’s 2013 opinion. The resolution adopted Parliament’s first-reading position, urging the Commission to re-submit the proposal if intending significant changes and instructing the President to transmit the decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments. The process adhered to Treaty obligations (Article 100(2) TFEU) and emphasized procedural compliance, including the Interinstitutional Agreement on recasting legal acts, while maintaining the substance of prior legislation.

title: Maritime spatial planning and integrated coastal management: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council establishing a framework for maritime spatial planning and integrated coastalmanagement
background: The EU’s extensive coastline, maritime economic significance (40% GDP), and rising cross-sectoral maritime activities (energy, shipping, tourism) prompted concerns over resource competition and ecosystem protection. The Parliament will discuss establishing a framework for coordinated maritime spatial planning and integrated coastal management to balance economic growth with environmental sustainability.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly agrees the integration of maritime spatial planning as essential for blue growth and job creation in coastal regions, aligning perfectly with EPP's commitment to sustainable economic development.  
EPP approves the framework's emphasis on ecological protection zones like Natura 2000, ensuring marine biodiversity conservation while advancing renewable energy infrastructure such as offshore wind farms.  
EPP proposes enhancing cross-border coordination with non-EU Adriatic states to address shared marine ecosystems, suggesting bilateral agreements to extend Directive principles without violating subsidiarity.  
EPP endorses decentralized implementation through member-state-led planning, effectively advancing EPP's priority of subsidiarity in coastal management and island development strategies.  
EPP highlights the issue's alignment with EU energy security goals by optimizing seabed resource exploitation and reducing reliance on external fossil fuel suppliers.

EFD rejects the proposal as a violation of subsidiarity, entirely challengeing with its principle that maritime resource management must remain under national jurisdiction.  
EFD opposes centralized EU spatial planning frameworks, arguing they disregard member states' sovereignty over exclusive economic zones and coastal infrastructure.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of regional autonomy, failing to address EFD's demand for decentralized decision-making in aquaculture and port development.  
EFD condemns the issue's EU-level policy coherence mandates as incompatible with its stance against supranational interference in energy and transport sectors.  
 While individual EFD members praised maritime growth potential, the party collectively rejects the directive’s legal encroachment on national competences.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's exclusion of binding Integrated Coastal Zone Management (ICZM) requirements, which completely condemns with their principle of holistic ecosystem protection.  
GREEN_EFA opposes weakening ICZM provisions through ambiguous phrasing like "where applicable," as this undermines enforceable safeguards for fragile coastal environments.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the dilution of participatory decision-making frameworks, a critical omission inconsistent with their commitment to democratic environmental governance.  
GREEN_EFA demands mandatory cross-border ICZM integration, rejecting the issue’s failure to address policy coherence between maritime and terrestrial planning.  
GREEN_EFA highlights the proposal’s incompatibility with climate resilience goals, noting its silence on binding coastal adaptation measures aligned with the European Green Deal.

ALDE strongly approves the issue's emphasis on participatory governance involving local authorities and stakeholders in coastal management.  
ALDE approves prioritizing renewable energy development, sustainable fisheries management, and transport infrastructure as foundational pillars for maritime spatial planning.  
ALDE proposes focusing initial implementation efforts on offshore wind/marine energy projects to accelerate decarbonization while maintaining ecosystem safeguards.  
This aligns perfectly with ALDE's longstanding commitment to multi-level governance and regional empowerment in EU policymaking.  
ALDE highlights the transport modernization provisions as critical for enhancing blue economy competitiveness across Europe's coastal regions.

SD strongly promotes the framework for cross-border maritime planning as a catalyst for sustainable blue growth, aligning with their commitment to job creation in emerging sectors like marine renewables.  
SD approves the mandatory ecosystem-based approach to address Mediterranean environmental pressures, effectively advancing SD’s priority of balancing economic and ecological needs.  
SD emphasizes the critical amendment ensuring free public access to coastal zones, preventing privatization while supporting recreational and cultural activities.  
SD endorses the Adriatic-Ionian macro-regional strategy as a model for transnational cooperation, reflecting SD’s vision for policy coherence in maritime economies.  
SD proposes strengthening Article 3 to explicitly define ecosystem thresholds for maritime zones, enhancing environmental safeguards without disrupting the directive’s core structure.

ECR strongly upholds the directive's emphasis on member state competence in coastal planning, aligning with their commitment to subsidiarity and national sovereignty over EU mandates.  
ECR approves the improved recognition of existing national frameworks but proposes revising the 36-month implementation deadline to ensure realistic adaptation of established coastal management systems.  
ECR advocates maintaining exclusive national control over economic zone designations in Mediterranean waters to prevent unsustainable external exploitation of marine resources.  
ECR endorses stakeholder-driven maritime spatial planning as critical for balancing tourism development with fisheries protection, reflecting regional economic priorities.  
ECR highlights the need to preserve flexibility in Articles 4-6 by reducing prescriptive detail, ensuring the directive functions as a guideline rather than a rigid template.

resolution: The European Parliament raised concerns regarding a 2013 Commission proposal (COM(2013)0133) on policies linked to transport, agriculture, environment, and energy, as outlined under relevant Treaty provisions. It highlighted objections from 10 national parliaments—Belgium, Germany, Ireland, Lithuania, the Netherlands, Poland, Finland, and Sweden—arguing the proposal violated subsidiarity principles. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism, alongside opinions from the Environment and Fisheries committees, and referenced advisory positions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. Parliament formally adopted its first-reading position, urging the Commission to resubmit the proposal if substantial revisions were planned, while emphasizing the need to align the legislation with EU competences and policy coherence across the affected sectors.

title: Introduction of noise-related operating restrictions at European Union airports: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on the establishment of rules and procedures with regard to the introduction of noise-related operating restrictions at Union airports within a Balanced Approach and repealing Directive 2002/30/EC of the European Parliament and of the Council
background: The European Commission proposed a regulation to replace Directive 2002/30/EC, addressing noise management at EU airports amid growing air traffic and varying national measures. The Parliament will discuss establishing harmonized rules for noise-related operating restrictions under the ICAO Balanced Approach framework.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts maintaining the 80/20 slot historicity rule to preserve market stability and avoid burdens on struggling airlines, aligning with their commitment to predictable regulatory frameworks.  
EPP strongly endorses reducing Commission oversight on noise restrictions to uphold subsidiarity, ensuring local authorities retain final decision-making power over airport operating limits.  
EPP proposes returning ground handling services provisions to committee for enhanced social clauses and training standards while supporting moderate liberalization from two to three providers as a balanced market enhancement.  
EPP approves strengthened transparency in secondary slot markets to prevent carrier abuse, matching their 2023 manifesto priorities for fair competition.  
EPP emphasizes the need to align noise mitigation measures with WHO health guidelines while respecting economic realities, urging clearer ICAO compliance in Article 2 wording.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's economic prioritization allowing operators to override local noise curfews, firmly disapproveing with health protections mandated by WHO guidelines as stressed by Eva Lichtenberger.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the Commission's authority to overturn regional flight restrictions, directly contradicting Michael Cramer's example of Frankfurt's hard-won night flight ban being jeopardized.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the exclusion of binding noise thresholds based on WHO standards, overlooking critical public health consequences emphasized by Isabelle Durant regarding premature mortality risks.  
GREEN_EFA rejects the subsidization of airlines through tax exemptions, opposing Michael Cramer's argument that this creates unfair competition against environmentally sustainable rail transport.  
GREEN_EFA totally disputes liberalizing ground handling services, which Eva Lichtenberger warned would institutionalize social dumping and degrade labor conditions at airports.

ALDE strongly promotes the balanced approach to noise regulation that maintains airport operational capacity while addressing health concerns, aligning with their commitment to market efficiency and public welfare.  
ALDE endorses maintaining member states' discretion in implementing operating restrictions to account for specific local infrastructure constraints like Frankfurt's expanded runway system.  
ALDE proposes enhancing worker qualification standards for ground handling services to complement liberalization measures, ensuring quality without opposing the core regulatory framework.  
ALDE approves the issue’s flexibility for smaller airlines in service time allocation but suggests clarifying "regular" service intervals to prevent unintended operational disruptions.  
ALDE applauds the emphasis on subsidiarity in noise management as effectively advancing their principle of EU-level coordination respecting national competencies.

SD completely agrees the harmonized procedural framework for noise-related operating restrictions, which perfectly aligns with their commitment to EU-wide environmental health standards while respecting subsidiarity through localized stakeholder negotiations.  
SD applauds the issue's integration of public health considerations into aviation policy, advancing their manifesto priority for science-based environmental protections through standardized noise impact assessments.  
SD strongly upholds the modernization of slot allocation mechanisms to optimize infrastructure use, recognizing this as complementary to noise reduction goals through efficient flight scheduling.  
SD emphasizes the necessity of maintaining strict social conditionality clauses in parallel legislation to ensure worker protections remain integral to all airport service reforms.  
SD acknowledges the issue's repeal of Directive 2002/30/EC as a critical evolution toward coherent EU aviation governance, eliminating redundant bureaucracy while preserving member states' operational flexibility.

ECR rejects the conversion of noise management from a directive to a binding regulation as a fundamental breach of subsidiarity principles, directly conflicting with their stance on national competence in local airport governance.  
ECR opposes the imposition of indeterminate minimum quality requirements in groundhandling services, arguing they create unnecessary bureaucratic burdens inconsistent with market liberalization goals.  
ECR fundamentally objects to the proposal's failure to exempt regional airports below 50,000 annual movements, citing its disproportionate impact demonstrated by cases like George Best City Airport.  
ECR condemns the issue's interference with established ICAO/CAPE compliance frameworks, viewing additional EU-layer restrictions as duplicative and harmful to aviation competitiveness.  
ECR disputes the economic rationale behind slot allocation reforms, noting the absence of Commission evidence demonstrating systemic abuse under current systems.

GUE/NGL rejects the proposal's centralization of noise regulation authority under Article 10, demanding member states retain control over airport operating restrictions based on local conditions.  
GUE/NGL opposes fundamentally the liberalization framework enabling wage suppression and precarious employment in ground services, citing degraded worker rights and passenger safety risks.  
GUE/NGL condemns the issue's failure to prioritize health over profit, advocating mandatory operational restrictions as the primary noise mitigation measure.  
GUE/NGL highlights the proposal's contradiction with social protections, noting monopolistic practices increase costs while eroding labor conditions and environmental safeguards.  
 While one member endorsed slot allocation reforms, GUE/NGL maintains overarching rejection due to unresolved worker exploitation and safety compromises.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 legislative proposal (COM(2011)0828) concerning transport infrastructure, emphasizing compliance with EU treaty principles and addressing objections from the French Senate, German Bundesrat, and Netherlands Senate, which argued the proposal violated subsidiarity by encroaching on national competencies. The resolution incorporated input from the Committee on Transport and Tourism and the Committee on the Environment, Public Health, and Food Safety, while acknowledging opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee and the Committee of the Regions. It formally adopted its stance, urged the Commission to re-engage Parliament if proposing significant amendments, and directed its President to communicate the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to ensure alignment with EU legislative procedures and subsidiarity principles.

title: Groundhandling services at Union airports: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council on groundhandling services at Union airports and repealing Council Directive 96/67/EC
background: The European Commission's 2011 proposal to update EU groundhandling services regulations followed long-standing concerns about market efficiency and service quality under Directive 96/67/EC. The Parliament will discuss proposed revisions to groundhandling service regulations addressing competition frameworks, operational standards, and workforce protections at Union airports.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly promotes rejecting the Commission’s proposal for violating subsidiarity, emphasizing national authority in airport service regulation as foundational to market stability.  
EPP approves maintaining the 80/20 slot allocation rule and opposing mandatory "slot reservation fees" to prevent undue burdens on airlines during economic challenges.  
EPP proposes allowing a moderate increase to three groundhandling providers at capacity-constrained airports as a targeted enhancement for competition, while rejecting blanket liberalization.  
EPP emphasizes reinforcing social clauses and worker training standards, aligning with quality improvements achieved through cross-committee collaboration on labor protections.  
EPP endorses Parliament’s prioritization of local decision-making on noise restrictions, ensuring regional authorities retain final oversight over environmental and operational balances.

EFD conditionally sanctions the proposal's competition objectives but demands revision of Article 3 to explicitly prohibit slot allocation mechanisms preserving legacy carrier advantages.  
The proposal fundamentally disputes with EFD's subsidiarity stance by imposing EU-wide noise standards; amendments must restrict regulatory authority to municipalities where airports predate residential developments.  
EFD rejects the issue's infrastructure harmonization framework as inconsistent with national sovereignty principles, requiring deletion of Section 2.1(b) on centralized technical specifications.  
The text overlooks critical market realities by failing to address historical land-use decisions; EFD insists on adding temporal priority clauses exempting airports operational before adjacent urbanization.  
EFD requests major revisions to Chapter IV to prohibit compensation claims from residents who voluntarily occupied noise-affected zones, aligning with personal responsibility principles.

GREEN_EFA rejects the proposal's failure to prevent social dumping and degradation of airport workers' conditions, totally disapproveing with their commitment to fair labor standards.  
GREEN_EFA opposes the attack on local noise regulations as dangerously inconsistent with WHO health guidelines and community-led environmental protections.  
GREEN_EFA condemns the unnecessary liberalization push for multiple groundhandling operators, which disregards evidence that competition worsens service quality without passenger benefits.  
GREEN_EFA denounces the proposal's implicit subsidy to airlines through lax noise enforcement, directly contradicting their demand for equitable transport taxation favoring railways.  
GREEN_EFA rejects Commission overreach into regional airport governance as a violation of subsidiarity principles central to their environmental justice agenda.

ALDE strongly agrees maintaining member states' autonomy to tailor groundhandling liberalization to local infrastructure capacities, aligning with subsidiarity principles.  
ALDE approves the rejection of uniform EU-level mandates, emphasizing that service quality hinges on worker qualifications and conditions rather than provider quantity.  
ALDE endorses prioritizing airport-specific realities like Frankfurt’s spatial constraints, which necessitate national flexibility over rigid competition rules.  
ALDE proposes enhancing future proposals with harmonized EU worker training standards to ensure quality alongside managed market expansion.  
ALDE applauds safeguarding regional aviation efficiency by allowing tailored slot allocation adjustments for smaller carriers during maintenance periods.

SD strongly advocates the rejection of the Commission’s proposal, emphasizing its alignment with prioritizing worker protections and service quality over market competition expansion.  
SD proposes enhancing future legislation with binding collective agreements and automatic staff transfers between service providers to safeguard labor rights.  
SD underscores the necessity for EU-wide minimum training standards and wage protections to prevent social dumping in airport operations.  
SD endorses maintaining strict safety protocols, rejecting measures that risk fragmenting workforce expertise and operational reliability.  
SD urges the Commission to reintroduce revised rules requiring enforceable social clauses and structured worker consultation processes.

GUE_NGL rejects the proposal as it enables wage dumping and jeopardizes passenger safety, fundamentally doubting with their commitment to workers' rights and public welfare.  
GUE_NGL opposes Article 10’s expansion of Commission oversight, demanding local autonomy in airport noise regulations to prioritize community health over corporate profits.  
GUE_NGL fully conflicts liberalization policies that degrade working conditions, citing evidence of job insecurity, wage cuts, and threats to aviation safety.

resolution: The European Parliament raised objections to the Commission’s 2011 proposal (COM(2011)0824), rejecting it due to concerns over non-compliance with the principle of subsidiarity, as highlighted by the Luxembourg Chamber of Deputies, and citing critical opinions from the European Economic and Social Committee (2012) and the Committee of the Regions (2012). The resolution emphasized that the proposal failed to justify EU-level intervention over national measures, particularly in harmonizing rules for implementing transport infrastructure guidelines. Parliament formally rejected the proposal, urged the Commission to withdraw it entirely, and instructed its President to communicate this decision to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments, underscoring the need to respect subsidiarity in legislative processes.

title: Recording equipment in road transport: REPORT on the proposal for a regulation of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Regulation (EEC) No 3821/85 on recording equipment in road transport and amending Regulation (EC) No 561/2006 of the European Parliament and the Council
background: Existing EU regulations on road transport recording equipment (EEC 3821/85, EC 561/2006) faced challenges including tachograph fraud, high compliance costs, and uneven enforcement. Technological advancements prompted calls for modernized systems. The Parliament will discuss amendments to enhance tachograph reliability, reduce administrative burdens, and harmonize enforcement of driving time and rest period rules.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly upholds enhanced tachograph security measures to combat fraud and align with road safety priorities in Article 91 TFEU, particularly endorsing mandatory encryption upgrades and harmonized control officer training.  
EPP approves the migration strategy for next-generation digital tachographs as critical to maintaining Single Market integrity while proposing stricter compatibility timelines to prevent transitional loopholes.  
EPP totally promotes binding categorizations of serious infringements to eliminate unfair competition from operators violating driving time rules, matching their 2023 transport safety manifesto commitments.  
EPP recommends limiting national derogations for non-professional drivers to prevent regulatory fragmentation, urging a unified 2.8-ton threshold exemption to simplify cross-border trade compliance.  
EPP emphasizes extending this framework's anti-fraud mechanisms to address wage dumping concerns raised during debate, proposing future amendments to integrate social condition monitoring.

EFD rejects the issue's expanded weight thresholds in Amendments 136 and 134 as entirely condemning with EFD's defense of small businesses against disproportionate surveillance.  
EFD opposes the retrofitting requirements for cement transport operations, which overlook critical aspects of material viability and contradict sector-specific flexibility principles.  
EFD condemns the proposal's failure to address bureaucratic suffocation of road haulers, directly opposing EFD's core commitment to reducing administrative burdens.  
EFD challenges the disregard for existing legislation like the 2002 Working Time Directive, creating inconsistent regulatory layers that undermine operational stability.  
EFD entirely condemns with the issue's calibration mandates, viewing them as unjustified intrusions into industry self-management capacities.

GREEN_EFA strongly upholds the issue’s advancement of digital tachograph standards, aligning perfectly with their commitment to road safety and fair working conditions in transport.  
GREEN_EFA proposes clarifying Article 6 to ensure rest periods only commence after work tasks like loading/unloading conclude, preventing systemic underreporting of driver activity.  
GREEN_EFA advocates reinstating speed monitoring parameters in Annex II and mandating weight sensors to address critical gaps in accident prevention mechanisms.  
GREEN_EFA urges the inclusion of an anonymous EU-wide whistleblower platform in Article 12 revisions to deter data manipulation and strengthen compliance.  
GREEN_EFA emphasizes integrating animal welfare checks during transport inspections through amended Chapter V to uphold comprehensive safety and ethical standards.

ALDE totally opposes with the proposal's reduction of vehicle weight limits to 2.8 tonnes, which imposes disproportionate bureaucratic burdens on craft professionals using light commercial vehicles.  
ALDE rejects Amendment 134's 100 km threshold as inconsistent with SME operational realities, advocating instead for Amendment 129's 150 km derogation to align with red tape reduction priorities.  
The proposal overlooks critical aspects of non-professional driver exemptions, particularly for tradespeople making occasional long-distance trips without commercial transport purposes.  
ALDE opposes the issue's failure to maintain existing national flexibility measures that currently protect small businesses from excessive tachograph requirements.  
This regulatory approach contradicts ALDE's 2020 strategy commitments to prioritize SME competitiveness through targeted deregulation in transport sector reforms.

SD strongly agrees the expansion of digital tachograph monitoring to vehicles under 2.8 tonnes, aligning perfectly with SD's longstanding commitment to road safety and fair competition by ensuring comprehensive oversight of professional drivers.  
SD applauds the harmonization of control officer training and penalty standardization, which effectively advances SD's priority of worker protection and equitable enforcement across Member States.  
SD proposes reviewing the 50 km exception for regular passenger bus services to enhance safety, suggesting amending Article 10(4) of Regulation (EC) No 561/2006 to prioritize accident prevention without opposing the issue’s core framework.  
SD emphasizes the critical need for strict rest-period compliance in passenger transport, particularly endorsing Amendment 149’s weight-sensor integration to prevent tragedies like the Karlovac motorway crash.  
SD urges monitoring financial impacts on SMEs during tachograph implementation, advocating for streamlined compliance procedures under Article 3 of Regulation 3821/85 to avoid disproportionate administrative burdens.

ECR rejects the proposal's merger of driving licences with tachograph records as a fundamental violation of privacy rights, disproportionately penalizing drivers in both professional and private capacities.  
ECR opposes satellite tracking mandates as regulatory overreach inconsistent with principles of limited state surveillance, framing this as "Big Brother’s eye in the sky" incompatible with individual liberties.  
ECR completely doubts with the issue’s cost imposition on transport businesses, arguing it exacerbates financial strain during economic fragility without proven safety ROI.  
The proposal overlooks critical enforcement harmonization needs, failing to address divergent national interpretations of driving time rules that directly undermine road safety objectives.  
ECR condemns the failure to prioritize cross-border Ecocombi adoption over intrusive technical measures, misaligning with practical freight efficiency improvements.

resolution: The European Parliament raised its position on the Commission’s 2011 transport sector proposal (COM(2011)0451), stressing alignment with Treaty on the Functioning of the European Union objectives under Article 91 and incorporating consultations with the European Economic and Social Committee (December 2011 opinion) and the Committee of the Regions. Based on the Committee on Transport and Tourism’s 2012 report (A7-0195/2012), it formally adopted its first-reading stance, urged the Commission to resubmit the proposal if introducing major amendments to ensure parliamentary scrutiny, and directed its President to transmit the position to the Council, Commission, and national parliaments to proceed with legislative deliberations.

title: Registration documents for vehicles: REPORT on the proposal for a directive of the European Parliament and of the Council amending Council Directive 1999/37/EC on the registration documents for vehicles
background: The EU's 1999 vehicle registration framework faced inconsistencies in cross-border documentation standards and data-sharing mechanisms, with member states applying divergent technical inspection protocols. The Parliament will discuss updating registration rules to align documentation formats, streamline re-registration processes, and enhance interoperability of national vehicle databases.

stances.stance:
EPP strongly accepts the harmonization of vehicle registration documents as a critical step toward EU-wide transport safety and administrative efficiency, aligning perfectly with EPP's longstanding commitment to single market optimization.  
EPP approves enhanced cargo security protocols in Articles 4-6, particularly mandating uniform inspection standards across borders to prevent load-shifting accidents and ensure fair competition among hauliers.  
EPP proposes strengthening motorcycle inspection requirements through an independent EU-wide accident study before implementation, ensuring evidence-based policymaking while maintaining road safety priorities.  
EPP endorses the electronic vehicle passport system as effectively advancing their 2023 digital single market goals, with explicit safeguards for national data sovereignty in cross-border information requests.
